licence_overview:
$!Contact your professional body or regulator to find out if they offer anti-money laundering supervision.$! 

Supervision schemes provide information and practical advice on setting up and improving systems. Scheme officials will also visit your business to inspect your records.

Businesses that must register include:

* credit institutions
* financial institutions
* auditors, external accountants, tax advisers and insolvency practitioners
* independent legal professionals
* estate agents
* trust and company service providers
* high value dealers such as antique dealers
* casinos

##How to apply
Ask your regulator or professional body which scheme you can apply for.

You will need to become a member of a professional body if you want to join its supervision scheme.  

If you are already a member of an organisation - or if regulates your business - you may still need to register separately for supervision.

###Government bodies offering supervision

* HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)
* Financial Services Authority (FSA)
* Office of Fair Trading (OFT)
* Gambling Commission  
* Department for Business Innovation & Skills
* Department of Enterprise, Trade and Investment in Northern Ireland

###Professional bodies offering supervision:

* Association of Accounting Technicians
* Association of Chartered Certified Accountants
* Association of International Accountants
* Association of Taxation Technicians
* Chartered Institute of Management Accountants
* Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy
* Chartered Institute of Taxation
* Council for Licensed Conveyors
* Faculty of Advocates
* Faculty Office of the Archbishop of Canterbury
* General Council of the Bar
* General Council of the Bar of Northern Ireland
* Insolvency Practitioners Association
* Institute of Certified Bookkeepers
* Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales
* Institute of Chartered Accountants in Ireland
* Institute of Chartered Accountants of Scotland
* Institute of Financial Accountants
* International Association of Book-keepers
* Law Society
* Law Society of Scotland
* Law Society of Northern Ireland

##Fees
You usually pay an upfront fee and an annual fee. 

The cost will depend on the scheme, the size of your business and the risk of it being used for financial crime. 

##Penalties

You can be fined of prosecuted: 

* if you don't report suspicious activity to the [Serious Organised Crime Agency (SOCA)](https://www.ukciu.gov.uk/(sct3dnqovty1ocisb5hzfy45)/saronline.aspx "Serious Organised Crime Agency (SOCA)"){:rel="external"}
* your regulator finds out your your business isn't registered for supervision

You can also be fined by your supervising body for sending in forms late and not improving your systems in line with regulations, when asked to.

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
*[FSA]:Financial Services Authority
*[OFT]:Office of Fair Trading
*[SOCA]:Serious Organised Crime Agency
